name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: The Russian people will quickly feel the unacceptable pain of Putin's recklessness. These losses, in conjunction with the economic pain about to be inflicted, will be unsustainable for the despot more fearful of his own people than NATO. (4/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: In recent years, the Russian government has gone to painstaking lengths to hide their casualties lost in Syria and Ukraine from the Russian public. This will not be possible as thousands of U.S.-made Javelins continue to rain down on Russian troops. (3/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: Over the past year, the U.S. has provided a historic amount of defensive aid to Ukraine, over $650M. This puts Ukraine in the best possible position to defend its territory and wage a devastating battle against invading Russian forces. (2/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: Putin’s Cold War nostalgia will be his undoing. Ukrainians are fighting back, and the international community is working in concert to isolate Russia and leave Putin weaker than ever. (1/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: No economic or diplomatic tool is off the table, and Putin should remember that our commitments to our NATO allies in the Baltics and Eastern Europe under Article 5 are absolute. (4/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: Now is the time for the Biden administration to immediately implement the full range of prepared sanctions. My colleagues and I stand ready to join the administration in acting decisively to impose punishing costs on Putin and his accomplices. (3/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: We stand with the heroic defenders of Ukraine, and pray for the innocent civilians who will soon endure senseless suffering. (2/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: This evening's attack confirms the worst fears of the free world. Putin's invasion will be an unmitigated tragedy for the people of Ukraine, and he must be held accountable by a united and resolute international coalition. (1/4)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
Every year, I hear from constituents about how rising drug prices are straining their finances and making them fear for their future.

Enough is enough. Lowering drug prices isn't a partisan issue — it's about putting people over pharmaceutical profits and doing the right thing.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
Today, @RepAndyKimNJ, @RepHaleyStevens & I introduced the Capping Drug Costs for Seniors Act to protect Medicare beneficiaries from burdensome out-of-pocket costs.

Our bill will push drug companies and insurers to pay their fair share & save seniors thousands of dollars a year.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
From 2012 - 2017, Medicare drug prices soared at nearly 10x the rate of inflation. 

Without a cap on out-of-pocket costs for Medicare Part D, seniors are struggling to make ends meet. After spending their working lives paying into Medicare, they deserve better.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
Big pharma needs to be held accountable for price-gouging working families. 

That's why @EleanorNorton, @RepRaskin, @RepSpanberger and I introduced the #SPIKEAct to require drug manufacturers to publicly justify price hikes to lawmakers and the public.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
For years, big pharma has hiked the prices of drugs (and made record profits) while families struggle to foot the bill.

In the wealthiest country on earth, no one should have to choose between putting food on the table and getting the medications they need to stay alive.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
In 2013, I had heart surgery — and since then, just like millions of Americans, I’ve needed to take daily medications to stay healthy for my family.

I know that drug prices are too high. Today, I introduced two bills to fix that (THREAD).

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
Last night, I attended a candlelight vigil in Tulsa, honoring the victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.

We must continue to uplift the stories of the survivors while shining a light on the impact of this tragic event. https://t.co/oEPmaVj7uT

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
This week, I'm joining my @TheBlackCaucus colleagues to bring attention to the Massacre and demand justice for survivors and their descendants.

Together, we honor the memory of Greenwood — and we push for the equity and restorative justice that is long-overdue. (9/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: The devastation of the Tulsa Race Massacre has been ignored and suppressed by official records, but it has never been forgotten by the Black community. (8/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
100 years later, the Black community in Tulsa is still struggling from the damage of the Tulsa Race Massacre.

In 1920, Black and white residents had nearly identical homeownership rates. Today, white Tulsans are nearly twice as likely to own a home as Black Tulsans. (7/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
The Tulsa Race Massacre crushed the center of Black wealth in America.

Over the next 100 years, the impact of the Massacre could be seen in lower net worth, educational attainment, and home ownership for Black families in Tulsa. (6/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
In the wake of the Tulsa Race Massacre, at least 9,000 people were left homeless and penniless.

A 2001 state commission report detailed that residents claimed $1.8 million in property loss — an equivalent of $27 million in today’s dollars — for the damage done that night. (5/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
The Tulsa Race Massacre resulted in as many as 300 deaths, and the destruction of thousands of homes and businesses.

More than 800 people were admitted to hospitals, and up to 6,000 Black residents were imprisoned, many for several days. Greenwood would never be the same. (4/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: The night of May 31, a violent white mob descended on the Greenwood District, torching homes and businesses, brutally assaulting and killing anyone in their way, and looting what was left in the wake. (3/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
Greenwood was a beacon of hope for Black Americans across the country. It was an example of what Black families could achieve, despite the segregation and bigotry of the time.

Then in roughly 48 hours, Greenwood was destroyed. (2/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
100 years ago, the Greenwood District of Tulsa was the wealthiest Black community in America.

Known as "Black Wall Street", Greenwood was a bright and vibrant place where Black professionals and their families could flourish and build wealth. (1/9)

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
100 years ago, a violent mob attacked the Greenwood District of Tulsa, destroying the wealthiest Black community in the US & killing hundreds.

This week, I'm joining my colleagues in @TheBlackCaucus to honor the survivors & push for long-overdue justice.

https://t.co/zyMxBD0Trs

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: The Senate is limiting EIP and cutting back UI. Americans need this money, and the difference between $400 and $300 is the difference between being able to afford rent, groceries, and life saving medication.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: On the anniversary of the #VotingRightsAct, let’s remember the enormous achievement of this legislation while also recognizing that the fight to restore the Voting Rights Act continues.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: Today, exactly 55 years later, during one of the most important elections of our lives, we’re again finding ourselves fighting to protect and defend the bedrock power of our democracy -- the right to vote.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: When the #VotingRightsAct was originally passed in 1965, it ensured that American citizens were not denied the right to vote based on their race, color, or the language they spoke.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text: Many Nevadans have been able to get back to work safely, but several industries remain slow to recover. That is why Congress must extend unemployment for individuals unable to work and provide support to workers returning safely.

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
tweet_text:
The Back on Your Feet Act would:
✔️Extend federal unemployment benefits
✔️Provide one-time “Back on Your Feet Pay” of $3,600
✔️Protect workers from losing unemployment benefits if they can’t return safely
✔️Provide additional $2 billion to help states process unemployment apps

name: Rep. Steven Horsford
